Sparse Networks with Random Weights for

Sparse Random Networks for
Communication-Efficient Federated Learning

Berivan Isik¶ ,  Francesco Pase§∗,  Deniz Gunduz‡,   Tsachy Weissman¶,   Michele Zorzi§
¶Stanford University, §University of Padova, ‡Imperial College London
berivan.isik@stanford.edu, pasefrance@dei.unipd.it First two authors contributed equally. Work done while F.P. was visiting Imperial College London.
Abstract

One main challenge in federated learning is the large communication cost of exchanging weight updates from clients to the server at each round. While prior work has made great progress in compressing the weight updates through gradient compression methods, we propose a radically different approach that does not update the weights at all. Instead, our method freezes the weights at their initial random values and learns how to sparsify the random network for the best performance. To this end, the clients collaborate in training a stochastic binary mask to find the optimal sparse random network within the original one. At the end of the training, the final model is a sparse network with random weights – or a subnetwork inside the dense random network. We show improvements in accuracy, communication (less than 111 bit per parameter (bpp)), convergence speed, and final model size (less than 111 bpp) over relevant baselines on MNIST, EMNIST, CIFAR-10, and CIFAR-100 datasets, in the low bitrate regime.

1 Introduction

Federated learning (FL) is a distributed learning framework where clients collaboratively train a model by performing local training on their data and by sharing their local updates with a server every few iterations, which in turn aggregates the local updates to create a global model, that is then transmitted to the clients for the next round of training. While being an appealing approach for enabling model training without the need to collect client data at the server, uplink communication of local updates is a significant bottleneck in FL (Kairouz et al., 2021). This has motivated research in communication-efficient FL strategies (McMahan et al., 2017a) and various gradient compression schemes via sparsification (Lin et al., 2018; Wang et al., 2018; Barnes et al., 2020; Ozfatura et al., 2021; Isik et al., 2022), quantization (Alistarh et al., 2017; Wen et al., 2017; Bernstein et al., 2018; Mitchell et al., 2022), and low-rank approximation (Konečnỳ et al., 2016; Vargaftik et al., 2021; 2022; Basat et al., 2022). In this work, while aiming for communication efficiency in FL, we take a radically different approach from prior work, and propose a strategy that does not require communication of weight updates. To be more precise, instead of training the weights,

(1) the server initializes a dense random network with d𝑑d weights, denoted by the weight vector 𝒘init=(w1init,w2init,…,wdinit)superscript𝒘initsubscriptsuperscript𝑤init1subscriptsuperscript𝑤init2…subscriptsuperscript𝑤init𝑑\bm{w^{\text{init}}}=(w^{\text{init}}_{1},w^{\text{init}}_{2},\dots,w^{\text{init}}_{d}), using a random seed 𝖲𝖤𝖤𝖣𝖲𝖤𝖤𝖣\mathsf{SEED}, and broadcasts 𝖲𝖤𝖤𝖣𝖲𝖤𝖤𝖣\mathsf{SEED} to the clients enabling them to reproduce the same 𝒘initsuperscript𝒘init\bm{w^{\text{init}}} locally,

(2) both the server and the clients keep the weights frozen at their initial values 𝒘initsuperscript𝒘init\bm{w^{\text{init}}} at all times,

(3) clients collaboratively train a probability mask of d𝑑d parameters 𝜽=(θ1,θ2,…,θd)∈[0,1]d𝜽subscript𝜃1subscript𝜃2…subscript𝜃𝑑superscript01𝑑\bm{\theta}=(\theta_{1},\theta_{2},\dots,\theta_{d})\in[0,1]^{d},

(4) the server samples a binary mask from the trained probability mask and generates a sparse network with random weights – or a subnetwork inside the initial dense random network as follows

𝒘final=Bern​(𝜽)⊙𝒘init,superscript𝒘finaldirect-productBern𝜽superscript𝒘init\bm{w^{\text{final}}}=\text{Bern}(\bm{\theta})\odot\bm{w^{\text{init}}}, (1)

where Bern​(⋅)Bern⋅\text{Bern}(\cdot) is the Bernoulli sampling operation and ⊙direct-product\odot the element-wise multiplication.

We call the proposed framework Federated Probabilistic Mask Training (𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼\mathtt{FedPM}) and summarize it in Figure 1. At first glance, it may seem surprising that there exist subnetworks inside randomly initialized networks that could perform well without ever modifying the weight values. This phenomenon has been explored to some extent in prior work (Zhou et al., 2019; Ramanujan et al., 2020; Pensia et al., 2020; Diffenderfer & Kailkhura, 2020; Aladago & Torresani, 2021) with different strategies for finding the subnetworks. However, how to find these subnetworks in a FL setting has not attracted much attention so far. Some exceptions to this are works by Li et al. (2021); Vallapuram et al. (2022); Mozaffari et al. (2021), which provide improvements in other FL challenges, such as personalization and poisoning attacks, while not being competitive with existing (dense) compression methods such as QSGD (Alistarh et al., 2017), DRIVE (Vargaftik et al., 2021), and SignSGD (Bernstein et al., 2018) in terms of accuracy under the same communication budget. In this work, we propose a stochastic way of finding such subnetworks while reaching higher accuracy at a reduced communication cost – less than 1 bit per parameter (bpp).

In addition to the accuracy and communication gains, our framework also provides an efficient representation of the final model post-training by requiring less than 1 bpp to represent (i) the random seed that generates the initial weights 𝒘initsuperscript𝒘init\bm{w^{\text{init}}}, and (ii) a sampled binary vector Bern​(𝜽)Bern𝜽\text{Bern}(\bm{\theta}) (computed with the trained 𝜽𝜽\bm{\theta}). Therefore, the final model enjoys a memory-efficient deployment – a crucial feature for machine learning at power-constrained edge devices. Another advantage our framework brings is the privacy amplification under some settings, thanks to the stochastic nature of our training strategy.

Our contributions can be summarized as follows:

(1) We propose a FL framework, in which the clients do not train the model weights, but instead a stochastic binary mask to be used in sparsifying the dense network with random weights. This differs from the standard training approaches in the literature.

(2) Our framework provides efficient communication from clients to the server by requiring (less than) 111 bpp per client while yielding faster convergence and higher accuracy than the baselines.

(3) We propose a Bayesian aggregation strategy at the server side to better deal with partial client participation and non-IID data splits.

(4) The final model (a sparse network with random weights) can be efficiently represented with a random seed and a binary mask which requires (less than) 1 bpp – at least 32×32\times more efficient storage and communication of the final model with respect to standard FL strategies.

(5) We demonstrate the efficacy of our strategy on MNIST, EMNSIT, CIFAR-10, and CIFAR-100 datasets under both IID and non-IID data splits; and show improvements in accuracy, bitrate, convergence speed, and final model size over relevant baselines, under various system configurations.

2 Related Work

In this section, we briefly discuss the related work in (1) communication-efficient FL, (2) pruning for FL, and (3) finding subnetworks in a random network.

Communication-Efficient FL.

One way of improving communication efficiency in FL is to compress the model updates using gradient compression methods like sparsification (Aji & Heafield, 2017; Lin et al., 2018; Wang et al., 2018; Barnes et al., 2020; Ozfatura et al., 2021; Isik et al., 2022), quantization (Alistarh et al., 2017; Wen et al., 2017; Suresh et al., 2017; Bernstein et al., 2018; Mitchell et al., 2022), and low-rank approximation (Wang et al., 2018; Vogels et al., 2019; Vargaftik et al., 2021; 2022; Mohtashami et al., 2022; Basat et al., 2022); or more FL-oriented compression schemes such as (Konečnỳ et al., 2016; McMahan et al., 2017a; Sattler et al., 2019; Rothchild et al., 2020; Reisizadeh et al., 2020; Haddadpour et al., 2020; 2021), while training a dense network. Our framework differs from these dense compression methods substantially due to the unconventional stochastic mask training strategy; however, we take SignSGD (Bernstein et al., 2018), TernGrad (Wen et al., 2017), QSGD (Alistarh et al., 2017), DRIVE (Vargaftik et al., 2021), and EDEN (Vargaftik et al., 2022) as our baselines since they work in the same bitrate regime as ours (≈\approx1 bpp).

Pruning for FL.

Since the introduction of the Lottery Ticket Hypothesis (LTH) (Frankle & Carbin, 2018), there has been growing interest in finding sparse and trainable networks at initialization. The main hypothesis in this line of work is that there exist sparse networks (lottery tickets) inside randomly initialized dense networks such that those sparse networks can be trained to a surprisingly good performance. In the original paper, the strategy for finding these lottery tickets is to iteratively train the dense network, i.e., finding the lottery tickets is expensive. We distinguish our approach from the FL papers that utilize the LTH (Li et al., 2020; Ji et al., 2020; Seo et al., 2021) and pruning (Lin et al., 2020; Munir et al., 2021; Yu et al., 2021; Liu et al., 2021; Jiang et al., 2022; Babakniya et al., 2022; Dai et al., 2022; Lin et al., 2020; Bibikar et al., 2022) for three mains reasons: (i) These methods require training the weight values, and thus cannot provide an efficient representation of the final model as 𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼\mathtt{FedPM} does. Recall that we achieve at least 32×32\times more efficient storage and communication of the final model by representing it with just a random seed and a binary mask. (ii) Some of these works require finding the lottery tickets prior to FL training (Li et al., 2020). While this could improve the communication cost during the FL training since they communicate sparse networks, it increases the computation cost significantly due to the burden of finding lottery tickets via training. (iii) As opposed to the LTH- or pruning-based FL works, our framework learns with what probability a particular weight should stay in the final model, i.e., the final sparsity level is also a learned parameter optimized for the best performance. Overall, since 𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼\mathtt{FedPM} is not in the same bitrate regime as these works (they require higher bitrates to communicate continuous weight values), we do not compare against them.

Finding Subnetworks Inside a Random Network.

Our work is closest to recent works of Zhou et al. (2019); Ramanujan et al. (2020); Pensia et al. (2020); Aladago & Torresani (2021), which find subnetworks (or supermasks) inside a dense network with random weights that perform surprisingly well without ever training the weights, but in a centralized scenario. In this work, we take advantage of the existence of such subnetworks to reduce the communication budget in FL to less than 1 bpp with faster convergence and higher accuracy than our relevant baselines in the same bitrate regime, while further compressing the final model, all simultaneously. Prior works (Li et al., 2021; Vallapuram et al., 2022; Mozaffari et al., 2021) also consider finding subnetworks inside a dense random network in a FL setting, but they differ from our approach on several levels. For instance, they focus on different challenges in FL, such as personalization and poisoning attacks, which limits their ability to improve over existing compression methods in accuracy-communication bitrate tradeoff. One fundamental reason for this is their deterministic mask training strategy, which involves hard thresholding or sign operations. On the other hand, the stochasticity in 𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼\mathtt{FedPM} allows us to (i) enjoy a better accuracy-communication cost tradeoff, (ii) have an unbiased estimate of the true aggregate of the local masks with a provable upper bound on the error, (iii) design an improved aggregation strategy with a Bayesian approach so that the previous masks at the server are not hard replaced – a useful strategy specifically in unbalanced non-IID splits, and (iv) gain privacy benefits via amplification in the Bernoulli sampling step. To demonstrate these benefits over deterministic schemes, we compare our method against FedMask (Li et al., 2021) by adapting it slightly to mainly focus on communication efficiency, rather than personalization, and to improve its accuracy-communication efficiency performance. More specifically, we discard the initial pruning stage that was deployed for personalization. This change was necessary because (a) this paper does not study personalization, so this pruning step would put FedMask at a disadvantage in our experimental setup, and (b) the initial pruning step requires extra training at client devices, which is computationally more expensive than 𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼\mathtt{FedPM} and the dense baselines.

3 Federated Probabilistic Mask Training (𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼\mathtt{FedPM})

We first describe the simpler version of the 𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼\mathtt{FedPM} framework in Section 3.1, which provides an unbiased estimation of the mean of the learned probability masks at the server with bounded error. Next, we propose a modification in our aggregation strategy by exploiting the underlying Bernoulli mechanism in Section 3.2. This helps boost the performance of 𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼\mathtt{FedPM} in the case of partial client participation. We then discuss the details of the distribution of the initial weights in Section 3.3, and finally describe the privacy benefits of 𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼\mathtt{FedPM} in Section 3.4. We use capital letters for random variables, small letters for their realization and deterministic quantities, and bold letters for vectors. Moreover, we indicate with 𝒙u,tsuperscript𝒙𝑢𝑡\bm{x}^{u,t} the state of the local vector 𝒙𝒙\bm{x} (e.g., the local mask) at client u𝑢u during round t𝑡t, and with xiu,tsubscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑢𝑡𝑖x^{u,t}_{i} its i𝑖i-th component. Global values are denoted with 𝒙g,tsuperscript𝒙𝑔𝑡\bm{x}^{g,t} and xig,tsubscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑔𝑡𝑖x^{g,t}_{i}, and sets are indicated with calligraphic fonts. We denote a neural network with weight vector 𝒑𝒑\bm{p} as f𝒑subscript𝑓𝒑f_{\bm{p}}.

3.1 𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼\mathtt{FedPM}

In this section, we present the general 𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼\mathtt{FedPM} training pipeline. First, the server randomly initializes a neural network f𝒘initsubscript𝑓superscript𝒘initf_{\bm{w}^{\text{init}}}, parameterized by the weight vector 𝒘init=(w1init,w2init,…,wdinit)∈ℝdsuperscript𝒘initsubscriptsuperscript𝑤init1subscriptsuperscript𝑤init2…subscriptsuperscript𝑤init𝑑superscriptℝ𝑑\bm{w}^{\text{init}}=(w^{\text{init}}_{1},w^{\text{init}}_{2},\dots,w^{\text{init}}_{d})\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, whose components are sampled IID according to a distribution P𝒘subscript𝑃𝒘P_{\bm{w}} using a randomly generated seed 𝖲𝖤𝖤𝖣𝖲𝖤𝖤𝖣\mathsf{SEED}. The random 𝖲𝖤𝖤𝖣𝖲𝖤𝖤𝖣\mathsf{SEED} value is then communicated to all the clients, which can locally sample the same pseudo-random vector 𝒘initsuperscript𝒘init\bm{w}^{\text{init}}, which is kept fixed and never modified during training. The goal for the clients is to collaboratively train a probability mask 𝜽∈[0,1]d𝜽superscript01𝑑\bm{\theta}\in[0,1]^{d}, which indicates the Bernoulli parameters for the global stochastic binary mask 𝑴∼Bern​(𝜽)∈{0,1}dsimilar-to𝑴Bern𝜽superscript01𝑑\bm{M}\sim\text{Bern}(\bm{\theta})\in\{0,1\}^{d}, such that the function f𝑾˙subscript𝑓bold-˙𝑾f_{\bm{\dot{W}}} maximizes its performance on a given task, where 𝑾˙=𝑴⊙𝒘initbold-˙𝑾direct-product𝑴superscript𝒘init\bm{\dot{W}}=\bm{M}\odot\bm{w}^{\text{init}}. Specifically, 𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼\mathtt{FedPM} learns the probabilities for the weights of being active, which are given by the probability mask 𝜽=(θ1,θ2,…,θd)∈[0,1]d𝜽subscript𝜃1subscript𝜃2…subscript𝜃𝑑superscript01𝑑\bm{\theta}=(\theta_{1},\theta_{2},\dots,\theta_{d})\in[0,1]^{d}. To achieve this, at every round t𝑡t, the server samples a set 𝒦tsubscript𝒦𝑡\mathcal{K}_{t} of |𝒦t|=Ksubscript𝒦𝑡𝐾|\mathcal{K}_{t}|=K participants (out of the total N𝑁N clients), which individually train their local probability masks 𝜽k,t,k∈𝒦tsuperscript𝜽𝑘𝑡𝑘subscript𝒦𝑡\bm{\theta}^{k,t},k\in\mathcal{K}_{t}, by using their local datasets 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}_{k}, each composed of Dk=|𝒟k|subscript𝐷𝑘subscript𝒟𝑘D_{k}=|\mathcal{D}_{k}| samples. These local masks are then aggregated by the server in a communication-efficient way to estimate the optimal 𝜽𝜽\bm{\theta}. At test time, at the server, the initial random network f𝒘initsubscript𝑓superscript𝒘initf_{\bm{w}^{\text{init}}} is sparsified using the global probability mask 𝜽g,tsuperscript𝜽𝑔𝑡\bm{\theta}^{g,t}, following the stochastic approach in Figure 1. In the following sections, we provide more details on each step of each round. We give the pseudocode for 𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼\mathtt{FedPM} in Appendix A.

3.1.1 Local Training of Probability Masks

Upon receiving a global probability mask 𝜽g,t−1superscript𝜽𝑔𝑡1\bm{\theta}^{g,t-1} from the server at the beginning of round t𝑡t, the client k𝑘k performs local training and updates the mask via back-propagation. First, however, we have to guarantee that the updated probability mask satisfies 𝜽k,t∈[0,1]dsuperscript𝜽𝑘𝑡superscript01𝑑\bm{\theta}^{k,t}\in[0,1]^{d}. While this can be achieved with a regularization term in the loss, this may require clipping 𝜽k,t∈[0,1]dsuperscript𝜽𝑘𝑡superscript01𝑑\bm{\theta}^{k,t}\in[0,1]^{d} before taking a Bernoulli sample, especially in the early training stages. Clipping would then make the estimate at the server biased and hence lead to a slower convergence and lower accuracy. Therefore, similarly to the work of Zhou et al. (2019), we introduce another mask, called score mask 𝒔=(s1,s2,…,sd)∈ℝd𝒔subscript𝑠1subscript𝑠2…subscript𝑠𝑑superscriptℝ𝑑\bm{s}=(s_{1},s_{2},\dots,s_{d})\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, that has unbounded support and can be used to generate the probability masks through the one-to-one sigmoid function by setting 𝜽=Sigmoid​(𝒔)𝜽Sigmoid𝒔\bm{\theta}=\text{Sigmoid}(\bm{s}). Then, the procedure for local training of the probability mask at round t𝑡t is as follows (here, the steps from Step 2 to 4 describe one local iteration, which is repeated a number τ𝜏\tau of times as standard in FL (McMahan et al., 2017a)):

(1) The server sends the global probability mask 𝜽g,t−1superscript𝜽𝑔𝑡1\bm{\theta}^{g,t-1} to K𝐾K chosen clients, and the clients set 𝒔k,t=Sigmoid−1​(𝜽g,t−1)superscript𝒔𝑘𝑡superscriptSigmoid1superscript𝜽𝑔𝑡1\bm{s}^{k,t}=\text{Sigmoid}^{-1}(\bm{\theta}^{g,t-1}), where Sigmoid−1​(⋅)superscriptSigmoid1⋅\text{Sigmoid}^{-1}(\cdot) is the inverse of the sigmoid function.

(2) Then, the clients generate a binary mask by first transforming back 𝜽k,t=Sigmoid​(𝒔k,t)superscript𝜽𝑘𝑡Sigmoidsuperscript𝒔𝑘𝑡\bm{\theta}^{k,t}=\text{Sigmoid}(\bm{s}^{k,t}), and then sampling a binary mask 𝑴k,tsuperscript𝑴𝑘𝑡\bm{M}^{k,t} from 𝜽k,tsuperscript𝜽𝑘𝑡\bm{\theta}^{k,t} as shown in Figure 1: 𝒎k,t∼Bern​(𝜽k,t).similar-tosuperscript𝒎𝑘𝑡Bernsuperscript𝜽𝑘𝑡{\bm{m}^{k,t}\sim\text{Bern}(\bm{\theta}^{k,t}).}

(3) The sampled binary mask then sparsifies the initial weight vector 𝒘initsuperscript𝒘init\bm{w}^{\text{init}}: 𝒘˙k,t=𝒎k,t⊙𝒘init.superscript˙𝒘𝑘𝑡direct-productsuperscript𝒎𝑘𝑡superscript𝒘init\dot{\bm{w}}^{k,t}=\bm{m}^{k,t}\odot\bm{w}^{\text{init}}.

(4) 𝒘˙k,tsuperscript˙𝒘𝑘𝑡\dot{\bm{w}}^{k,t} is then used for forward pass, and the loss ℒ​(f𝒘˙k,t,𝒟k)ℒsubscript𝑓superscript˙𝒘𝑘𝑡subscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{L}(f_{\dot{\bm{w}}^{k,t}},\mathcal{D}_{k}) on the local task is backpropagated to update the score mask as 𝒔k,t=𝒔k,t−η​∇ℒ​(f𝒘˙k,t,𝒟k)superscript𝒔𝑘𝑡superscript𝒔𝑘𝑡𝜂∇ℒsubscript𝑓superscript˙𝒘𝑘𝑡subscript𝒟𝑘\bm{s}^{k,t}=\bm{s}^{k,t}-\eta\nabla\mathcal{L}(f_{\dot{\bm{w}}^{k,t}},\mathcal{D}_{k}) (η𝜂\eta is the local learning rate).

All the local operations from Step 2 to Step 4 are differentiable, except for the Bernoulli sampling. We backpropagate the gradients through the Bernoulli sampling operation with a straight-through estimator Bengio et al. (2013), using the first-order gradient of the Bernoulli function, which is simply equal to the probability mask 𝜽k,tsuperscript𝜽𝑘𝑡\bm{\theta}^{k,t}.

3.1.2 Communication Strategy

Once the local training at round t𝑡t is completed, the server needs to distill the global probability mask 𝜽g,tsuperscript𝜽𝑔𝑡\bm{\theta}^{g,t}, by taking the empirical average of the local probability masks 𝜽¯g,t=1K​∑k∈𝒦t𝜽k,tsuperscript¯𝜽𝑔𝑡1𝐾subscript𝑘subscript𝒦𝑡superscript𝜽𝑘𝑡\bar{\bm{\theta}}^{g,t}=\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}_{t}}\bm{\theta}^{k,t} collected from the clients. However, since we aim for communication efficiency, the clients do not send their local probability masks directly. Instead, they communicate a stochastic binary sample 𝑴k,tsuperscript𝑴𝑘𝑡\bm{M}^{k,t} from their probability masks sampled as 𝒎k,t∼Bern​(𝜽k,t)similar-tosuperscript𝒎𝑘𝑡Bernsuperscript𝜽𝑘𝑡\bm{m}^{k,t}\sim\text{Bern}(\bm{\theta}^{k,t}), and then the server estimates the global aggregate 𝜽¯g,tsuperscript¯𝜽𝑔𝑡\bar{\bm{\theta}}^{g,t} as 𝜽¯^g,t=1K​∑k∈𝒦t𝒎k,tsuperscript^¯𝜽𝑔𝑡1𝐾subscript𝑘subscript𝒦𝑡superscript𝒎𝑘𝑡\hat{\bar{\bm{\theta}}}^{g,t}=\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}_{t}}\bm{m}^{k,t}. This distributed mean estimation problem with communication constraints is summarized in Figure 2. Our estimator 𝜽¯^g,t=1K​∑k∈𝒦t𝒎k,tsuperscript^¯𝜽𝑔𝑡1𝐾subscript𝑘subscript𝒦𝑡superscript𝒎𝑘𝑡\hat{\bar{\bm{\theta}}}^{g,t}=\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}_{t}}\bm{m}^{k,t} is an unbiased estimate of the true aggregate, in that

𝔼𝑴k,t∼Bern​(𝜽k,t)​∀k∈𝒦t​[𝜽¯^g,t]subscript𝔼similar-tosuperscript𝑴𝑘𝑡Bernsuperscript𝜽𝑘𝑡for-all𝑘subscript𝒦𝑡delimited-[]superscript^¯𝜽𝑔𝑡\displaystyle\mathbb{E}_{\bm{M}^{k,t}\sim\text{Bern}(\bm{\theta}^{k,t})\ \forall k\in\mathcal{K}_{t}}[\hat{\bar{\bm{\theta}}}^{g,t}] =𝔼𝑴k,t∼Bern​(𝜽k,t)​∀k∈𝒦t​[1K​∑k∈𝒦t𝑴k,t]absentsubscript𝔼similar-tosuperscript𝑴𝑘𝑡Bernsuperscript𝜽𝑘𝑡for-all𝑘subscript𝒦𝑡delimited-[]1𝐾subscript𝑘subscript𝒦𝑡superscript𝑴𝑘𝑡\displaystyle=\mathbb{E}_{\bm{M}^{k,t}\sim\text{Bern}(\bm{\theta}^{k,t})\ \forall k\in\mathcal{K}_{t}}\left[\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}_{t}}\bm{M}^{k,t}\right]
=1K​∑k∈𝒦t𝔼𝑴k,t∼Bern​(𝜽k,t)​[Mk,t]absent1𝐾subscript𝑘subscript𝒦𝑡subscript𝔼similar-tosuperscript𝑴𝑘𝑡Bernsuperscript𝜽𝑘𝑡delimited-[]superscript𝑀𝑘𝑡\displaystyle=\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}_{t}}\mathbb{E}_{\bm{M}^{k,t}\sim\text{Bern}(\bm{\theta}^{k,t})}[M^{k,t}]
=1K​∑k∈𝒦t𝜽k,tabsent1𝐾subscript𝑘subscript𝒦𝑡superscript𝜽𝑘𝑡\displaystyle=\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}_{t}}\bm{\theta}^{k,t}
=𝜽¯g,t.absentsuperscriptbold-¯𝜽𝑔𝑡\displaystyle=\bm{\bar{\theta}}^{g,t}.

Moreover, the estimation error is upper bounded as (the proof is given in Appendix B)

𝔼𝑴k,t∼Bern​(𝜽k,t)​∀k∈𝒦t​[‖𝜽¯^g,t−𝜽¯g,t‖22]≤d4​K.subscript𝔼similar-tosuperscript𝑴𝑘𝑡Bernsuperscript𝜽𝑘𝑡for-all𝑘subscript𝒦𝑡delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptnormsuperscript^¯𝜽𝑔𝑡superscript¯𝜽𝑔𝑡22𝑑4𝐾\displaystyle\begin{aligned} \mathbb{E}_{\bm{M}^{k,t}\sim\text{Bern}(\bm{\theta}^{k,t})\ \forall k\in\mathcal{K}_{t}}\big{[}||\hat{\bar{\bm{\theta}}}^{g,t}-\bar{\bm{\theta}}^{g,t}||_{2}^{2}\big{]}\leq\frac{d}{4K}.\end{aligned} (2)

Since each client communicates a stochastic binary mask 𝑴k,tsuperscript𝑴𝑘𝑡\bm{M}^{k,t}, 1 bpp is the worst-case bitrate for 𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼\mathtt{FedPM}. We can further reduce the bitrate to less than 1 by using arithmetic coding (Rissanen & Langdon, 1979) or universal coding (Krichevsky & Trofimov, 1981; Barron et al., 1998) to encode 𝒎k,tsuperscript𝒎𝑘𝑡\bm{m}^{k,t}, and achieve the empirical entropy since d𝑑d is large. This gives us smaller bitrates whenever the frequency of 1’s in 𝒎k,tsuperscript𝒎𝑘𝑡\bm{m}^{k,t} is far from 0.5 – which is usually the case for our method (see Figure 3 and Appendix E.2 for results). We note that, with a deterministic mask training approach as in FedMask (Li et al., 2021), arithmetic coding of 𝒎k,tsuperscript𝒎𝑘𝑡\bm{m}^{k,t}s does not provide any further gain in bitrate, as we have empirically observed that the frequency of 1’s is always around 0.5 (see Figure 3 and Appendix E.2) – here we apply arithmetic coding for FedMask to improve our baseline although it was not proposed in the original paper. Moreover, FedMask (Li et al., 2021) and HideNSeek (Vallapuram et al., 2022) do not enjoy the guarantees we have as their estimator (i) is not unbiased and (ii) does not have an upper bound on the estimation error due to hard thresholding (Li et al., 2021) and sign operations (Vallapuram et al., 2022). This is another benefit of our stochastic sampling approach.

3.2 𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼\mathtt{FedPM} with Bayesian Aggregation

Another important aspect that differentiates our work from existing masking methods such as FedMask (Li et al., 2021) and HideNSeek (Vallapuram et al., 2022) is the Bayesian aggregation strategy, which exploits the underlying stochastic mask to synthesize a global model, boosting the performance in scenarios where only a fraction of the clients participate in each round. Given the probabilistic interpretation of the 𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼\mathtt{FedPM} mask’s values, at the server side we further model the probability mask 𝜽g,tsuperscript𝜽𝑔𝑡\bm{\theta}^{g,t} with a Beta distribution Beta​(𝜶g,t,𝜷g,t)Betasuperscript𝜶𝑔𝑡superscript𝜷𝑔𝑡\text{Beta}(\bm{\alpha}^{g,t},\bm{\beta}^{g,t}), parameterized by the round-dependent parameters 𝜶g,tsuperscript𝜶𝑔𝑡\bm{\alpha}^{g,t} and 𝜷g,tsuperscript𝜷𝑔𝑡\bm{\beta}^{g,t}, which are initialized to 𝜶g,0=𝜷g,0=𝝀𝟎superscript𝜶𝑔0superscript𝜷𝑔0subscript𝝀0\bm{\alpha}^{g,0}=\bm{\beta}^{g,0}=\bm{\lambda_{0}}. At the beginning of the training process, there is no prior knowledge indicating which network weight should be more important than the others, and so each entry in the probability mask is uniformly distributed in [0,1]01[0,1] – which is the prior distribution. Consequently, the clients’ local binary masks 𝑴k,tsuperscript𝑴𝑘𝑡\bm{M}^{k,t}s are the data the server uses to update its belief on each weight score, and so the aggregation strategy corresponds now to a posterior update. Specifically, given the conjugate relation between the Beta-Bernoulli distributions, the new posteriors are still Beta distributions with parameters

𝜶g,t=𝜶g,t−1+𝑴agg,tand𝜷g,t=𝜷g,t−1+K⋅𝟏−𝑴agg,t∀t≥1,formulae-sequencesuperscript𝜶𝑔𝑡superscript𝜶𝑔𝑡1superscript𝑴agg𝑡andformulae-sequencesuperscript𝜷𝑔𝑡superscript𝜷𝑔𝑡1⋅𝐾1superscript𝑴agg𝑡for-all𝑡1\displaystyle\bm{\alpha}^{g,t}=\bm{\alpha}^{g,t-1}+\bm{M}^{\text{agg},t}\quad\text{and}\quad\bm{\beta}^{g,t}=\bm{\beta}^{g,t-1}+K\cdot\bm{1}-\bm{M}^{\text{agg},t}\quad\forall t\geq 1, (3)

where 𝑴agg,t=∑k∈𝒦t𝑴k,tsuperscript𝑴agg𝑡subscript𝑘subscript𝒦𝑡superscript𝑴𝑘𝑡\bm{M}^{\text{agg},t}=\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}_{t}}\bm{M}^{k,t}, and 𝟏1\bm{1} is the d𝑑d-dimensional all-ones vector. Then, the server broadcasts to the clients the mode of the Bernoulli distributions, as suggested by Ferreira et al. (2021),

𝜽g,t=𝜶g,t−1𝜶g,t+𝜷g,t−2,superscript𝜽𝑔𝑡superscript𝜶𝑔𝑡1superscript𝜶𝑔𝑡superscript𝜷𝑔𝑡2\displaystyle\bm{\theta}^{g,t}=\frac{\bm{\alpha}^{g,t}-1}{\bm{\alpha}^{g,t}+\bm{\beta}^{g,t}-2}, (4)

where the division operation is applied element-wise. However, to obtain the best performance out of this method, the Beta parameters should be re-initialized to their original values 𝝀0subscript𝝀0\bm{\lambda}_{0} with some regularity. We present an ablation study to demonstrate the improvements gained by the Bayesian aggregation strategy and the reasonable choices for the resetting frequency in Section 4.3. Notice that if 𝝀0=𝟏subscript𝝀01\bm{\lambda}_{0}=\bm{1}, and if 𝜶𝜶\bm{\alpha} and 𝜷𝜷\bm{\beta} are re-initialized at the beginning of each round, the method is equivalent to the aggregation strategy detailed in Section 3.1.2.

3.3 Weight Distribution

As mentioned in Section 3.1, the fixed weight vector 𝒘initsuperscript𝒘init\bm{w}^{\text{init}} is initialized by sampling from the distribution Pwsubscript𝑃𝑤P_{w} using the randomly generated 𝖲𝖤𝖤𝖣𝖲𝖤𝖤𝖣\mathsf{SEED}. We note that the choice of this distribution impacts two important aspects of 𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼\mathtt{FedPM}: (i) the values of 𝒘initsuperscript𝒘init\bm{w}^{\text{init}} highly influence the final accuracy achieved by the model, as they represent the building blocks to extract a subnetwork f𝒘˙subscript𝑓˙𝒘f_{\dot{\bm{w}}} (see Figure 1), which should be rich enough to solve the learning task, and (ii) the size of the sample space of Pwsubscript𝑃𝑤P_{w} affects the number of bits needed to store the model during the inference process (this is different from the 1 bpp model storage when the model is not in use). Regarding (i), as also proposed in Ramanujan et al. (2020), we sample weights from a uniform distribution, whose domain is {−σ,+σ}𝜎𝜎\{-\sigma,+\sigma\}, where σ𝜎\sigma is the standard deviation of the Kaiming Normal distribution (He et al., 2015). In this way, we control the variance of the neurons’ output to be ∼1similar-toabsent1\sim 1, which avoids the vanishing or the explosion of activation values. Previous experiments in (Zhou et al., 2019; Ramanujan et al., 2020) also demonstrate the superior performance achieved by binary weights distributions when compared to standard continuous counterparts, e.g., Gaussian. Regarding (ii), even if knowing the value of 𝖲𝖤𝖤𝖣𝖲𝖤𝖤𝖣\mathsf{SEED} is enough to perfectly reconstruct the vector 𝒘initsuperscript𝒘init\bm{w}^{\text{init}}, one would have to generate the entire vector at every inference step. Consequently, to achieve fast inference, the actual values of the weights need to be stored in the memory of the devices during the inference process. Fortunately, our initialization allows for efficient storage even during inference since (after reconstructing 𝒘finalsuperscript𝒘final\bm{w}^{\text{final}} using 𝖲𝖤𝖤𝖣𝖲𝖤𝖤𝖣\mathsf{SEED} and 𝒎final∈{0,1}dsuperscript𝒎finalsuperscript01𝑑\bm{m}^{\text{final}}\in\{0,1\}^{d}) we only need to indicate whether the weight values in 𝒘finalsuperscript𝒘final\bm{w}^{\text{final}} are −σ𝜎-\sigma, 00, or +σ𝜎+\sigma, with a ternary representation that can be efficiently deployed on hardware (Alemdar et al., 2017).

3.4 Privacy

Privacy is another challenge in FL as the model updates (in our case, 𝑴k,tsuperscript𝑴𝑘𝑡\bm{M}^{k,t}s) may leak information about the client data. In Appendix C, we analyze the differential privacy guarantees of 𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼\mathtt{FedPM} and give an initial foray into how 𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼\mathtt{FedPM} can be helpful in amplifying privacy.

4 Experiments

In this section, we empirically show the performance of 𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼\mathtt{FedPM} in terms of accuracy, bitrate, converge speed, and the final model size. We consider four datasets: CIFAR-10 with 10 classes, CIFAR-100 (Krizhevsky et al., 2009) with 100 classes, MNIST (Deng, 2012) with 10 classes, and EMNIST (Cohen et al., 2017) with 47 classes. For CIFAR-100, we use a 10-layer convolutional network (CNN) 𝙲𝙾𝙽𝚅𝙲𝙾𝙽𝚅\mathtt{CONV}-𝟷𝟶10\mathtt{10} and ResNet-18 He et al. (2016); for CIFAR-10, a 6-layer CNN 𝙲𝙾𝙽𝚅𝙲𝙾𝙽𝚅\mathtt{CONV}-𝟼6\mathtt{6} and ResNet-18 He et al. (2016); and for MNIST and EMNIST, a 4-layer CNN 𝙲𝙾𝙽𝚅𝙲𝙾𝙽𝚅\mathtt{CONV}-𝟺4\mathtt{4}. A detailed description of the architectures can be found in Appendix D. Due to limited space, we provide the results on ResNet-18 in Appendix E.1. We first compare 𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼\mathtt{FedPM} with SignSGD (Bernstein et al., 2018), TernGrad (Wen et al., 2017), QSGD (Alistarh et al., 2017), DRIVE (Vargaftik et al., 2021), EDEN (Vargaftik et al., 2022), and FedMask (Li et al., 2021) on IID data split and full client participation in Section 4.1. We then extend our experiments to non-IID data splits and partial participation in Section 4.2. Finally, in Section 4.3, we present a key ablation study to justify why the Bayesian aggregation strategy is necessary for partial participation and to demonstrate how the resetting frequency affects the convergence rate and the final accuracy. Clients perform 3 local epochs in all experiments. We provide additional details on the experimental setup in Appendix D. We present results averaged over 3 runs.

4.1 IID Data Split and Full Participation (K=N𝐾𝑁K=N)

In this section, we focus on IID data distribution and the case when all the clients participate in the training at each round. We set the number of clients to N=K=10𝑁𝐾10N=K=10. We report the estimated bitrate for the arithmetic code that uses the empirical frequency of the symbols (for our method 𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼\mathtt{FedPM}, this corresponds to the frequency of 1’s in 𝒎k,tsuperscript𝒎𝑘𝑡\bm{m}^{k,t}) – which is equal to the empirical entropy for blocklength d𝑑d as large as the model size. In Figure 3, we compare the accuracy, bitrate, and convergence speed of 𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼\mathtt{FedPM} with relevant baselines. As can be seen in the figure, 𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼\mathtt{FedPM} converges to the highest accuracy on all four datasets. DRIVE, EDEN, and QSGD (they mostly overlap in the accuracy plots) seem to be the three baselines that perform the best after 𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼\mathtt{FedPM}; however, their convergence speed is significantly lower than 𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼\mathtt{FedPM}. In terms of convergence speed, FedMask is the fastest among the baselines – in fact, at the beginning of the training, FedMask is faster than 𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼\mathtt{FedPM} as well. However, its final accuracy is lower than the others. We also would like to highlight that while some of our baselines, such as FedMask and TernGrad, have a visibly high variance in accuracy, 𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼\mathtt{FedPM} shows stable training behavior across all experiments.

In terms of bitrate, SignSGD and FedMask consistently spend 1 bpp, which is the default number when a binary mask or sign mask is communicated. This means binary values (1’s and 0’s) are almost equally distributed in their masks, which prevents them from enjoying additional bitrate gains. Across all experiments, TernGrad has the highest bitrate. We would like to leave a note about the bitrate of QSGD. Unlike other baselines, including our work, QSGD can go down to very low bitrates by adjusting the number of levels in quantization. We have observed that in the extreme quantization case, QSGD underperforms 𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼\mathtt{FedPM}. Then, we have decided to increase the number of quantization levels in QSGD to see if it improves the accuracy. However, as can be seen from the plots, even with bitrate larger than 1, QSGD still underperforms 𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼\mathtt{FedPM}. The only two baselines that challenge 𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼\mathtt{FedPM} in terms of bitrate are DRIVE and EDEN. While 𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼\mathtt{FedPM} has lower bitrates on CIFAR-10 and EMNIST; DRIVE and EDEN have better bitrates on CIFAR-100 and MNIST. However, the accuracy of DRIVE and EDEN on these datasets (specifically CIFAR-100) is significantly lower than that of 𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼\mathtt{FedPM}, with slower convergence.

As for the final model size, 𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼\mathtt{FedPM} needs only 0.8 bpp for the 𝙲𝙾𝙽𝚅𝙲𝙾𝙽𝚅\mathtt{CONV}-𝟼6\mathtt{6} model trained on CIFAR-10, 0.85 bpp for the 𝙲𝙾𝙽𝚅𝙲𝙾𝙽𝚅\mathtt{CONV}-𝟷𝟶10\mathtt{10} model trained on CIFAR-100, 0.96 bpp for the 𝙲𝙾𝙽𝚅𝙲𝙾𝙽𝚅\mathtt{CONV}-𝟺4\mathtt{4} model trained on MNIST, and 0.83 bpp for the 𝙲𝙾𝙽𝚅𝙲𝙾𝙽𝚅\mathtt{CONV}-𝟺4\mathtt{4} model trained on EMNIST. On the other hand, other baselines that train a dense model, namely SignSGD, TernGrad, QSGD, DRIVE, and EDEN, would need to represent each weight with their full precision value, i.e., 32 bpp. This implies that 𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼\mathtt{FedPM} provides around 38.6×38.6\times improvement in the storage or the communication of the final model. Since FedMask also trains a sparse model, it enjoys a similar gain in the final model size requiring 1 bpp across all the models. Due to the stochastic masking procedure and uneven distribution of 111’s and 00’s in the binary masks, 𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼\mathtt{FedPM} has up to 0.17 bpp improvement over the deterministic procedure in FedMask, which adds up to a large gain due to the huge model size.

We provide additional experimental results with ResNet-18 model on CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100 datasets in Appendix E.1; and observe similar improvements over the baselines.

4.2 Non-IID Data Split and Partial Participation (K<N𝐾𝑁K<N)

This section considers more realistic scenarios, in which the local clients’ datasets are generated from slightly different data distributions. We focus on CIFAR-10 with 𝙲𝙾𝙽𝚅𝙲𝙾𝙽𝚅\mathtt{CONV}-𝟼6\mathtt{6}, and we compare 𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼\mathtt{FedPM} against (i) the most promising baselines, which, based on the results of Section 4.1, are DRIVE, EDEN, and QSGD, and (ii) FedMask, as it is the only sparse baseline. To choose the size of each dataset |𝒟n|=Dnsubscript𝒟𝑛subscript𝐷𝑛|\mathcal{D}_{n}|=D_{n}, for each client n∈{1,…,N}𝑛1…𝑁n\in\{1,\dots,N\}, an integer jnsubscript𝑗𝑛j_{n} is sampled uniformly from {10,11,…,100}1011…100\{10,11,\dots,100\}. Then, a coefficient pn=jn∑njjsubscript𝑝𝑛subscript𝑗𝑛subscript𝑛subscript𝑗𝑗p_{n}=\frac{j_{n}}{\sum_{n}j_{j}} is computed, which represents the size of the local dataset Dnsubscript𝐷𝑛D_{n} as a fraction of the size of the full dataset, i.e., the training set of CIFAR-10. In this way, highly unbalanced datasets can be generated from the central one. Moreover, since the task is a classification problem, we impose a maximum number of different labels, or classes, cmaxsubscript𝑐maxc_{\text{max}}, that one client can see. Consequently, clients need cooperation to learn the statistics of other classes’ distributions, as the test dataset contains samples from all classes. In addition, partial participation is also considered, meaning that at each round, the server uniformly samples a fraction ρ=KN𝜌𝐾𝑁\rho=\frac{K}{N} of the clients to participate in the training round. This is motivated in real-world scenarios by the scarcity of physical communication network resources, which may limit the availability of part of the clients during one round. The maximum number of classes per local dataset is set to cmax∈{2,4}subscript𝑐max24c_{\text{max}}\in\{2,4\}, and the participation ratio is set to ρ∈{0.1,0.2,0.5,1}𝜌0.10.20.51\rho\in\{0.1,0.2,0.5,1\}. For ρ=1𝜌1\rho=1 and ρ=0.5𝜌0.5\rho=0.5, the total number of clients is set to N=10𝑁10N=10 (and so K𝐾K is equal to 101010 and 555, respectively). For ρ=0.2𝜌0.2\rho=0.2, we set N=100𝑁100N=100 (and so K=20𝐾20K=20), and for ρ=0.1𝜌0.1\rho=0.1, we set N=50𝑁50N=50 (and so K=5𝐾5K=5), which is the worst scenario among all combinations, given the small amount of information the server can collect at the end of each round. When ρ=1𝜌1\rho=1, for the 𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼\mathtt{FedPM} algorithm, we keep the same aggregation strategy exposed in Section 3.1.2 and Figure 2; and we switch to the Bayesian aggregation method (see Section 3.2) when there is partial participation, i.e., when ρ<1𝜌1\rho<1. Indeed, applying the Bayesian aggregation method is revealed to be crucial for achieving good accuracy when ρ<1𝜌1\rho<1 and data are non-IID, obtaining a large gain with respect to the simpler version in Section 3.1.2, which resets the Beta priors at each round (or takes the average of the samples, as explained in Section 3.2). We elaborate more on this observation with an ablation study in Section 4.3. We adopt a simple heuristic schedule to reset the priors: Reset every 333 rounds when ρ=0.5𝜌0.5\rho=0.5 and ρ=0.2𝜌0.2\rho=0.2, and every 101010 rounds when ρ=0.1𝜌0.1\rho=0.1. As expected, the smaller the ratio ρ𝜌\rho, the larger the number of rounds we should wait before resetting the priors to collect more information from a much more diverse pool of clients (see Section 4.3 for a rule of thumb on the resetting frequency).

Table 1 reports the results with cmax=4subscript𝑐max4c_{\text{max}}=4 and 222. 𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼\mathtt{FedPM} seems to outperform all the baselines in every configuration, as the Bayesian aggregation allows the server to collect more data before resetting the priors, which is important when clients’ data distributions are non-IID, and only a fraction of the clients participate in each round. This strategy can be seen as the 𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼\mathtt{FedPM} counterpart of decreasing the learning rate (which we applied in the other dense compression-based baselines, like DRIVE, EDEN, and QSGD). It is seen from Table 1 that FedMask (Li et al., 2021) is struggling in the non-IID case, as applying a hard threshold on the scores to binarize the mask does not provide a proper way to implement multiple-rounds aggregation, emphasizing the benefit of the stochastic process in 𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼\mathtt{FedPM}. It is interesting to notice that, especially when cmax=4subscript𝑐max4c_{\text{max}}=4, the lower the value of ρ𝜌\rho, the larger the gap between 𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼\mathtt{FedPM} and the baselines, corroborating the fact that the Bayesian strategy can better deal with partial participation. Analysis of the communication bitrate is provided in Appendix. E.2.

4.3 Ablation Study on the Bayesian Aggregation Strategy

In this section, we try to answer two questions: (1) Is Bayesian aggregation really necessary? and (2) What is the effect of resetting frequency on the convergence rate and the final accuracy? We do this by analyzing the effect of different resetting frequencies of the Beta priors on the training behavior of 𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼\mathtt{FedPM} with non-IID data split and partial client participation; and report the results in Figure 4. Hereafter, we denote with γ𝛾\gamma the number of aggregation rounds before resetting the priors. For instance, γ=1𝛾1\gamma=1 corresponds to resetting the priors at every iteration, which is equivalent to the aggregation method presented in Section 3.1.2. On the other extreme, γ=200𝛾200\gamma=200 indicates that the priors are never reset. It is seen that γ=1𝛾1\gamma=1 curves fluctuate significantly and never converge to the best accuracy in any setting, while γ=200𝛾200\gamma=200 curves look smoother but converge to the lowest accuracy in all settings. This intuitively makes sense because, as already mentioned in Section 3.2, by increasing the value of γ𝛾\gamma, we allow the server to consider the information coming from multiple rounds while updating the global parameters. Indeed, with partial participation and non-IID data, a single round’s updates may convey skewed information, depending on the level of data heterogeneity cmaxsubscript𝑐maxc_{\text{max}}, and client participation ratio ρ𝜌\rho. As a rule of thumb for the resetting frequency value, we suggest tuning γ𝛾\gamma around the value 1ρ1𝜌\frac{1}{\rho}. The rationale behind this is that with uniform client sampling, at least 1ρ1𝜌\frac{1}{\rho} rounds are needed to have the non-zero probability to sample from each client once before resetting the prior. In practice, we do not need to sample exactly from every client, as enough information is contained in the updates of the other sampled ones.

5 Conclusion

In this work, we introduced Federated Probabilistic Mask Training (𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼\mathtt{FedPM}) – a communication-efficient FL strategy. 𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼\mathtt{FedPM} relies on the idea of finding a sparse network in a randomly initialized dense network, which is then sparsified by a collaboratively trained stochastic binary mask. In addition to reducing the communication cost to less than 111 bit per parameter (bpp), 𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼\mathtt{FedPM} also reaches higher accuracy with faster convergence than the relevant baselines, and can potentially amplify privacy while additionally outputting a compressed final model with a size less than 1 bpp. Throughout the manuscript, we highlighted the advantages of having a stochastic mask training approach rather than a deterministic one in terms of accuracy, bitrate, and privacy.

6 Ethics Statement

All the experiments in the paper were performed on publicly available datasets. When we evaluated our strategy, we only considered accuracy as a measure of performance. However, as pointed out by Hooker et al. (2020), compression methods may disproportionately impact different subgroups of the data. We agree that this may potentially create a fairness issue in all communication-efficient federated learning frameworks and deserves more attention from the community.

7 Reproduction Statement

The codebase for this work is open-sourced at https://github.com/BerivanIsik/sparse-random-networks. All the hyperparameters necessary to reproduce the results in the paper can be found in Appendix D. We only used publicly available standard datasets and included links to them in the manuscript.

Appendix B Proof of the Upper Bound on the Estimation Error

We now provide proof of the upper bound on the estimation error in Eq. 2. Appendix C Privacy Amplification and Bias Correction

Differential privacy (DP) guarantees that the probability of an outcome of an algorithm that runs on client data does not change much by a single client’s data. This is typically ensured via injecting noise to a function of the client data at a particular step in the algorithm with some utility loss in the application. While there have been many DP strategies developed for FL and deep learning (Abadi et al., 2016; McMahan et al., 2017b; Agarwal et al., 2021; Andrew et al., 2021), these strategies typically suffer from severe performance degradation due to noise injection. To make DP practical, researchers have explored certain randomization mechanisms that amplify the privacy guarantee. When these mechanisms are parts of the FL framework, such as sampling (data (Balle et al., 2018; Wang et al., 2019) or device (Balle et al., 2020; Girgis et al., 2021; Hasircioglu & Gunduz, 2022)) and shuffling (Erlingsson et al., 2019; Feldman et al., 2022), the amplification comes for free. This is helpful because the overall process can meet a stronger privacy guarantee without increasing the noise level. 𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼\mathtt{FedPM} promises one such amplification due to the stochastic Bernoulli sampling step. We first revisit the definitions of differential privacy (Dwork et al., 2006), Rényi divergence, and Rényi differential privacy (Mironov, 2017); and then present the amplification result.

Definition 1.

[Adjacent Datasets] Two datasets D,D′∈𝒟DsuperscriptD′𝒟D,D^{\prime}\in\mathcal{D} are called adjacent if they differ in at most one data sample.

Definition 2.

[(ϵ,δ)ϵδ\mathbf{(\epsilon,\delta)}-DP] A randomized mechanism f:𝒟→ℛ:f→𝒟ℛf:\mathcal{D}\rightarrow\mathcal{R} offers (ϵ,δ)ϵδ(\epsilon,\delta)-differential privacy if for any adjacent D,D′∈𝒟DsuperscriptD′𝒟D,D^{\prime}\in\mathcal{D} and 𝒮⊂ℛ𝒮ℛ\mathcal{S}\subset\mathcal{R}

Pr​[f​(D)∈𝒮]≤eϵ​Pr​[f​(D′∈𝒮)]+δ.Prdelimited-[]𝑓𝐷𝒮superscript𝑒italic-ϵPrdelimited-[]𝑓superscript𝐷′𝒮𝛿\displaystyle\text{Pr}[f(D)\in\mathcal{S}]\leq e^{\epsilon}\text{Pr}[f(D^{\prime}\in\mathcal{S})]+\delta.
Definition 3.

[Rényi Divergence] For two probability distributions PPP and QQQ defined over ℛℛ\mathcal{R}, the Rényi divergence of order α>1α1\alpha>1 is

Dα(P||Q)=1α−1log𝔼x∼Q(P​(x)Q​(x))α.\displaystyle D_{\alpha}(P||Q)=\frac{1}{\alpha-1}\log{\mathbb{E}_{x\sim Q}\left(\frac{P(x)}{Q(x)}\right)^{\alpha}}.
Definition 4.

[(α,ϵ)αϵ\mathbf{(\alpha,\epsilon)}-RDP] A randomized mechanism f:𝒟→ℛ:f→𝒟ℛf:\mathcal{D}\rightarrow\mathcal{R} offers ϵϵ\epsilon-Rényi differential privacy of order αα\alpha (or in short (α,ϵ)αϵ(\alpha,\epsilon)-RDP) if for any adjacent D,D′∈𝒟DsuperscriptD′𝒟D,D^{\prime}\in\mathcal{D}, it holds that

Dα(f(D)||f(D′))≤ϵ.\displaystyle D_{\alpha}(f(D)||f(D^{\prime}))\leq\epsilon.

In particular, Imola & Chaudhuri (2021) have shown that when a sample 𝑴∈{0,1}d𝑴superscript01𝑑\bm{M}\in\{0,1\}^{d} from an already privatized vector 𝜽∈[c,1−c]d𝜽superscript𝑐1𝑐𝑑\bm{\theta}\in[c,1-c]^{d}, where 0<c<0.50𝑐0.50<c<0.5, is released to a third party (instead of 𝜽𝜽\bm{\theta} itself), the privacy is amplified under some conditions. More precisely, when there is an (α,ϵ)𝛼italic-ϵ(\alpha,\epsilon)-Rényi Differential Privacy mechanism (Mironov, 2017) that privatizes 𝜽∈[c,1−c]d𝜽superscript𝑐1𝑐𝑑\bm{\theta}\in[c,1-c]^{d}, releasing a sample from Bern​(𝜽)Bern𝜽\text{Bern}(\bm{\theta}) yields an improved privacy budget (the smaller ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon, the better the privacy): ϵa​m​p≤min⁡{ϵ,d⋅rα​(c)}subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑎𝑚𝑝italic-ϵ⋅𝑑subscript𝑟𝛼𝑐\epsilon_{amp}\leq\min{\{\epsilon,d\cdot r_{\alpha}(c)\}}. Here, rα​(p)subscript𝑟𝛼𝑝r_{\alpha}(p) is the binary symmetric Rényi divergence function defined as rα​(p)=1α−1​log⁡(pα​(1−p)1−α+(1−p)α​p1−α)subscript𝑟𝛼𝑝1𝛼1superscript𝑝𝛼superscript1𝑝1𝛼superscript1𝑝𝛼superscript𝑝1𝛼r_{\alpha}(p)=\frac{1}{\alpha-1}\log{\left(p^{\alpha}(1-p)^{1-\alpha}+(1-p)^{\alpha}p^{1-\alpha}\right)}. Notice that 𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼\mathtt{FedPM} already involves this Bernoulli sampling step in the communication protocol and in the forward pass 𝒎k,t∼Bern​(𝜽k,t)similar-tosuperscript𝒎𝑘𝑡Bernsuperscript𝜽𝑘𝑡\bm{m}^{k,t}\sim\text{Bern}(\bm{\theta}^{k,t}). However, the d𝑑d term in the upper bound limits the amplification for large model sizes. We believe it is worth exploring a tighter upper bound on ϵa​m​psubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑎𝑚𝑝\epsilon_{amp} to enjoy privacy amplification in 𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼\mathtt{FedPM} with practical models. Nonetheless, in Appendix C, we demonstrate the impact of this amplification on a distributed mean estimation problem, described in Figure 2, where the goal is to estimate the true mean of the probability masks 𝜽¯=1K​∑k=1K𝜽k¯𝜽1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscript𝜽𝑘\bar{\bm{\theta}}=\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\bm{\theta}^{k} under communication and privacy constraints. We also provide a bias correction mechanism, specific to our scheme in Figure 5 in Appendix C, that mitigates the bias due to the DP mechanism and reduces the estimation error.

Now, suppose that we have an (α,ϵ)𝛼italic-ϵ(\alpha,\epsilon)-RDP algorithm f𝑓f that outputs privatized 𝜽k∈[c,1−c]dsuperscript𝜽𝑘superscript𝑐1𝑐𝑑\bm{\theta}^{k}\in[c,1-c]^{d} with 0<c<0.50𝑐0.50<c<0.5, using local client data 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}_{k}. As summarized in Figure 5, we are interested in what happens when instead of releasing 𝜽k=f​(𝒟k)superscript𝜽𝑘𝑓subscript𝒟𝑘\bm{\theta}^{k}=f(\mathcal{D}_{k}), the client k𝑘k releases a Bernoulli sample from it: 𝒎k∈{0,1}d∼Bern​(𝜽k)superscript𝒎𝑘superscript01𝑑similar-toBernsuperscript𝜽𝑘\bm{m}^{k}\in\{0,1\}^{d}\sim\text{Bern}(\bm{\theta}^{k}). We already explained the advantages in terms of communication bitrate, estimation error, unbiasedness throughout the manuscript; however, this approach also amplifies the privacy guarantees, meaning that it makes the overall privacy budget smaller ϵa​m​p≤ϵsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑎𝑚𝑝italic-ϵ\epsilon_{amp}\leq\epsilon. Quantitatively, Imola & Chaudhuri (2021) showed that after the Bernoulli sampling, the privacy budget of the overall process is

ϵa​m​p≤min⁡{ϵ,d​rα​(c)},subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑎𝑚𝑝italic-ϵ𝑑subscript𝑟𝛼𝑐\displaystyle\epsilon_{amp}\leq\min{\{\epsilon,dr_{\alpha}(c)\}},

where rα​(⋅)subscript𝑟𝛼⋅r_{\alpha}(\cdot) is the Rényi divergence of the binary symmetric function. More precisely, consider P,Q𝑃𝑄P,Q random variables with support on {x1,x2}⊂Θsubscript𝑥1subscript𝑥2Θ\{x_{1},x_{2}\}\subset\Theta and let p=Pr​[P=x1]𝑝Prdelimited-[]𝑃subscript𝑥1p=\text{Pr}[P=x_{1}], 1−p=Pr​(Q=x1)1𝑝Pr𝑄subscript𝑥11-p=\text{Pr}(Q=x_{1}). Then the Rényi divergence is defined as

rα​(p)=Rα​(P,Q)=1α−1​log⁡(pα​(1−p)1−α+(1−p)α​p1−α).subscript𝑟𝛼𝑝subscript𝑅𝛼𝑃𝑄1𝛼1superscript𝑝𝛼superscript1𝑝1𝛼superscript1𝑝𝛼superscript𝑝1𝛼\displaystyle r_{\alpha}(p)=R_{\alpha}(P,Q)=\frac{1}{\alpha-1}\log{(p^{\alpha}(1-p)^{1-\alpha}+(1-p)^{\alpha}p^{1-\alpha})}.

Notice that 𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼\mathtt{FedPM} already involves this Bernoulli sampling step in the communication protocol and in the forward pass 𝒎k,t∼Bern​(𝜽k,t)similar-tosuperscript𝒎𝑘𝑡Bernsuperscript𝜽𝑘𝑡\bm{m}^{k,t}\sim\text{Bern}(\bm{\theta}^{k,t}). This implies that 𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼\mathtt{FedPM} improves the privacy guarantee without changing the privacy mechanism – e.g. without increasing the injected noise level. However, the d𝑑d term in the upper bound limits the amplification for large model sizes. We believe it is worth exploring a tighter upper bound on ϵa​m​psubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑎𝑚𝑝\epsilon_{amp} to enjoy privacy amplification in 𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼\mathtt{FedPM} with practical models. Nonetheless, we demonstrate the impact of this amplification on a distributed mean estimation problem, described in Figure 5, where the probability masks 𝜽k∈[c,1−c]dsuperscript𝜽𝑘superscript𝑐1𝑐𝑑\bm{\theta}^{k}\in[c,1-c]^{d} are a function of client data 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}_{k}; and are first corrupted by Gaussian noise, and then clipped to the range [c,1−c]dsuperscript𝑐1𝑐𝑑[c,1-c]^{d}. Our goal is, as before, to estimate the true mean 𝜽¯=1K​∑k∈𝒦t𝜽kbold-¯𝜽1𝐾subscript𝑘subscript𝒦𝑡superscript𝜽𝑘\bm{\bar{\theta}}=\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}_{t}}\bm{\theta}^{k} by averaging the sampled binary masks, i.e., 𝜽¯^=1K​∑k∈𝒦t𝒎kbold-^bold-¯𝜽1𝐾subscript𝑘subscript𝒦𝑡superscript𝒎𝑘\bm{\hat{\bar{\theta}}}=\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}_{t}}\bm{m}^{k}. Differently from our previous experiments, we have privacy constraints now, meaning that we want to guarantee (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP by injecting a Gaussian noise with variance σ2=2​ln⁡(1.25/δ)​Δ22ϵ2superscript𝜎221.25𝛿superscriptsubscriptΔ22superscriptitalic-ϵ2\sigma^{2}=\frac{2\ln{(1.25/\delta)\Delta_{2}^{2}}}{\epsilon^{2}} with a small ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon, where δ≈1N2𝛿1superscript𝑁2\delta\approx\frac{1}{N^{2}} and Δ2subscriptΔ2\Delta_{2} is the ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}-sensitivity of the probability masks (in our case Δ2=(1−2​c)​dsubscriptΔ212𝑐𝑑\Delta_{2}=(1-2c)\sqrt{d}). We transfer the above amplification results in RDP to DP using the well-known relation:

Remark C.1.

Mironov (2017) showed that if f𝑓f is an (α,ϵ)𝛼italic-ϵ(\alpha,\epsilon)-RDP mechanism, it also satisfies (ϵ+log⁡1/δα−1,δ)italic-ϵ1𝛿𝛼1𝛿(\epsilon+\frac{\log{1/\delta}}{\alpha-1},\delta)-DP for any 0<δ<10𝛿10<\delta<1.

Since clipping after the noise addition step would lead to bias in the estimated mean, we work out a bias correction mechanism. We denote with θ𝜃\theta one general parameter at client k𝑘k for one parameter, with θ~~𝜃\tilde{\theta} its noisy version, and with θ^=clip​(θ~)^𝜃clip~𝜃\hat{\theta}=\text{clip}(\tilde{\theta}) its clipped version. Specifically, if θ~=θ+η~𝜃𝜃𝜂\tilde{\theta}=\theta+\eta is the noisy version of the parameter, where η∼𝒩​(0,σ2)similar-to𝜂𝒩0superscript𝜎2\eta\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\sigma^{2}), then

clip​(θ~)={θ~,ifc≤θ+η≤1−c1−c,ifθ+η>1−cc,ifθ+η<c.clip~𝜃cases~𝜃if𝑐𝜃𝜂1𝑐1𝑐if𝜃𝜂1𝑐𝑐if𝜃𝜂𝑐\text{clip}(\tilde{\theta})=\begin{cases}\tilde{\theta},&\text{if}\quad c\leq\theta+\eta\leq 1-c\\ 1-c,&\text{if}\quad\theta+\eta>1-c\\ c,&\text{if}\quad\theta+\eta<c.\end{cases} (13)

We now compute 𝔼​[M^]𝔼delimited-[]^𝑀\mathbb{E}\left[\hat{M}\right], where M^∼Bern​(θ^)similar-to^𝑀Bern^𝜃\hat{M}\sim\text{Bern}(\hat{\theta}), to analyze the bias 𝔼​[M^]−𝔼​[M]=𝔼​[M^]−θ𝔼delimited-[]^𝑀𝔼delimited-[]𝑀𝔼delimited-[]^𝑀𝜃\mathbb{E}\left[\hat{M}\right]-\mathbb{E}\left[M\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[\hat{M}\right]-\theta, where M∼Bern​(θ)similar-to𝑀Bern𝜃M\sim\text{Bern}(\theta). First of all, notice that

𝔼​[M^]𝔼delimited-[]^𝑀\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[\hat{M}\right] =∫01𝔼​[M^|θ^=ρ]​f​(ρ)​𝑑ρ=∫01ρ​f​(ρ)​𝑑ρ=𝔼​[θ^].absentsuperscriptsubscript01𝔼delimited-[]conditional^𝑀^𝜃𝜌𝑓𝜌differential-d𝜌superscriptsubscript01𝜌𝑓𝜌differential-d𝜌𝔼delimited-[]^𝜃\displaystyle=\int_{0}^{1}\mathbb{E}\left[\hat{M}|\hat{\theta}=\rho\right]f(\rho)d\rho=\int_{0}^{1}\rho f(\rho)d\rho=\mathbb{E}[\hat{\theta}].

And we now compute the mean of the clipped parameter

=1−c+[θ−1+c]​Φσ​(1−c−θ)+[c−θ]​Φσ​(c−θ)+−σ​e−(c−θ)22​σ22​π​[e−2​(c−θ)−1−1],absent1𝑐delimited-[]𝜃1𝑐subscriptΦ𝜎1𝑐𝜃delimited-[]𝑐𝜃subscriptΦ𝜎𝑐𝜃𝜎superscript𝑒superscript𝑐𝜃22superscript𝜎22𝜋delimited-[]superscript𝑒2𝑐𝜃11\displaystyle=1-c+[\theta-1+c]\Phi_{\sigma}(1-c-\theta)+[c-\theta]\Phi_{\sigma}(c-\theta)+\frac{-\sigma e^{\frac{-(c-\theta)^{2}}{2\sigma^{2}}}}{\sqrt{2\pi}}\left[e^{-2(c-\theta)-1}-1\right],

where Φσ​(⋅)subscriptΦ𝜎⋅\Phi_{\sigma}\left(\cdot\right) is the cumulative distribution function of a Gaussian random variable with standard deviation σ𝜎\sigma, and zero mean. We use this relation to correct the bias in 𝜽¯^bold-^bold-¯𝜽\bm{\hat{\bar{\theta}}}. In practice, to adopt the bias-correction strategy, we sample the function 𝔼​[θ^]𝔼delimited-[]^𝜃\mathbb{E}\left[\hat{\theta}\right], which is a function of the true parameter θ𝜃\theta, noise standard deviation σ𝜎\sigma, and clipping parameter c𝑐c, at Q𝑄Q different points x1,…,xQsubscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑄x_{1},\dots,x_{Q}, i.e., different values for the uncorrupted θ𝜃\theta, and we store the values in a table. Indeed, the values σ𝜎\sigma and c𝑐c are set at the beginning of the training process, secretly shared among the participants, and never modified. Then, once the server computes an estimate for θ^^𝜃\hat{\theta}, it corrects it by finding the closest outputs of 𝔼​[θ^]𝔼delimited-[]^𝜃\mathbb{E}\left[\hat{\theta}\right] in the stored table, and it inverts the map by choosing the corresponding xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i}, i.e., the original θ𝜃\theta.

We conduct our experiments with N=100𝑁100N=100 clients, each having independent probability masks with dimension d=5𝑑5d=5 and range [0.2,0.8]0.20.8[0.2,0.8], i.e., 𝜽∈[0.2,0.8]5𝜽superscript0.20.85\bm{\theta}\in[0.2,0.8]^{5}. Figure 6 shows the estimation error ‖𝜽¯^g,t−𝜽¯g,t‖22superscriptsubscriptnormsuperscriptbold-^bold-¯𝜽𝑔𝑡superscriptbold-¯𝜽𝑔𝑡22||\bm{\hat{\bar{\theta}}}^{g,t}-\bm{\bar{\theta}}^{g,t}||_{2}^{2} under no noise injection case (i.e. no DP) with the black line. Recall that we want to reach a smaller estimation error and smaller ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon (i.e., a stronger privacy guarantee). The red curve corresponds to the ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon vs. estimation error behavior if Bernoulli sampling did not amplify the privacy. The blue curve shows the amplified ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon (i.e. ϵa​m​p≤ϵsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑎𝑚𝑝italic-ϵ\epsilon_{amp}\leq\epsilon) vs. estimation error behavior, and it overlaps with the red curve for ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon values smaller than d⋅rα​(c)=8.96⋅𝑑subscript𝑟𝛼𝑐8.96d\cdot r_{\alpha}(c)=8.96, where there is no privacy amplification, i.e., ϵa​m​p=ϵsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑎𝑚𝑝italic-ϵ\epsilon_{amp}=\epsilon. However, notice that the blue line never reaches ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon’s higher than this value due to amplification, while enjoying smaller estimation errors that the red curve can only achieve with very large ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon. This shows the promise of 𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼\mathtt{FedPM} in having a better privacy-accuracy performance than most baselines that do not have amplification. Finally, the green curve shows that bias correction improves this performance further even with ϵ<d⋅rα​(c)=8.96italic-ϵ⋅𝑑subscript𝑟𝛼𝑐8.96\epsilon<d\cdot r_{\alpha}(c)=8.96 by achieving lower estimation errors with the same ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon.

Appendix D Additional Experimental Details

In Table 2, we provide the architectures for all the models used in our experiments. Clients performed 3 local epochs with a batch size of 128 and a local learning rate of 0.1 in all the experiments. Notice that there is no server learning rate in 𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼\mathtt{FedPM}; instead, we tune the prior resetting schedule in Bayesian aggregation for the experiments in Section 4.2. We conducted our experiments on NVIDIA Titan X GPUs on an internal cluster server, using 1 GPU per one run.

In the non-IID and partial participation experiments in Section 4.2, to distill the final model, we may apply both stochastic sampling, as during training, or a hard-threshold method, similar to the one adopted in FedMask (Li et al., 2021). In the latter, a binary mask coefficient misubscript𝑚𝑖m_{i} is set to 111 if θi>αthssubscript𝜃𝑖subscript𝛼ths\theta_{i}>\alpha_{\text{ths}}, and 00 otherwise. For all experiments but one, when αths∈[0.4,0.6]subscript𝛼ths0.40.6\alpha_{\text{ths}}\in[0.4,0.6], the thresholding test accuracy is always higher than the sampling method, and so we use the threshold method. However, in the extreme case cmax=2subscript𝑐max2c_{\text{max}}=2 and ρ=0.1𝜌0.1\rho=0.1, the optimal values for αmaxsubscript𝛼max\alpha_{\text{max}} were in [0.2,0.4]0.20.4[0.2,0.4] and [0.6,0.8]0.60.8[0.6,0.8] in all experiments, probably due to the high randomness given by the highly heterogeneous scenario. Consequently, for the last experiment, we just adopt the stochastic sampling strategy to evaluate the model, as further optimizing the αthssubscript𝛼ths\alpha_{\text{ths}} means adapting to the test dataset, which may corrupt the ability of the model to generalize.

Appendix E Additional Experimental Results

E.1 Additional Experiments on ResNet Architectures

In this section, we provide additional experimental results with ResNet-18 (He et al., 2016) on CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100 datasets. For these experiments, we focus on IID data distribution and the case when all the clients participate in the training at each round. We use the same hyperparameters from Section 4.1. We provide the details of the ResNet-18 architecture in Table 3 below.

Figures 7 and 8 show the results on CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100 datasets, respectively. It is seen that 𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼\mathtt{FedPM} outperforms all the baselines in terms of accuracy. Although DRIVE and EDEN require approximately 0.1 smaller bitrates than 𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼\mathtt{FedPM}, they also reach lower accuracy. In summary, the advantages of 𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼\mathtt{FedPM} discussed in the main manuscript carry over to ResNet-18 model as well.

E.2 Bitrate Considerations on non-iid Data

We now report the communication bitrate considerations on the non-IID data split experiments described in Section 4.2. Table 4 reports the average bitrate needed by different algorithms over the whole training process when cmax=4subscript𝑐max4c_{\text{max}}=4 and cmax=2subscript𝑐max2c_{\text{max}}=2. By simply multiplying the obtained average bitrate by the total number of rounds tmax=200subscript𝑡max200t_{\text{max}}=200, we obtain the total number of bits one element in the global probability mask needs to converge to its final value, indicating the total amount of information communicated during the training process.

We first observe that both DRIVE and EDEN consume almost the same amount of bits no matter the system configuration and round number (very small variance), and it is instead model dependent (see Figure 3). On the contrary, 𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼\mathtt{FedPM} and QSGD report higher bitrate variability, as it depends on both the training phase and system setting. As already observed in Section 4.1, FedMask balances almost uniformly the binary updates, leading to a bitrate that is basically fixed to 111. For both cmax=4subscript𝑐max4c_{\text{max}}=4 and cmax=2subscript𝑐max2c_{\text{max}}=2, 𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼\mathtt{FedPM} yields the smallest bitrate when ρ=1𝜌1\rho=1, whereas for the other scenarios, EDEN and DRIVE are slightly more efficient. We argue that this is motivated by the fact that, as the learning task becomes harder due to the high system heterogeneity, all the models struggle to converge to good and stable solutions, which means that 𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼\mathtt{FedPM} is still uncertain about the weights’ importance probabilities 𝜽𝜽\bm{\theta}, setting many of them close to 0.50.50.5. However, we think that this may be a useful feature of 𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼\mathtt{FedPM} to quantify its internal uncertainty, which we will further analyze.

To conclude the analysis, we also report the 𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼\mathtt{FedPM} bpp for the final model, which is an indication of the average number of bits needed per one parameter of the model. In the case of cmax=4subscript𝑐max4c_{\text{max}}=4, the final model sizes are 0.790.790.79 bpp, 0.8340.8340.834 bpp, and 0.990.990.99 bpp, when ρ={0.1,0.5,1}𝜌0.10.51\rho=\{0.1,0.5,1\}, respectively. When cmax=2subscript𝑐max2c_{\text{max}}=2, the final model sizes are 0.80.80.8 bpp, 0.8170.8170.817 bpp, and 0.9920.9920.992 bpp. Consequently, at the end of the training process, 𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼𝙵𝚎𝚍𝙿𝙼\mathtt{FedPM} remains the most efficient option, as already observed in Section 4.1.
